article:
Mohun Bagan Super Giant
==========================

Mohun Bagan Super Giant, commonly known as Mohun Bagan, is an Indian professional football club based in Kolkata, West Bengal. Founded in 1889, it is one of the oldest and most successful football clubs in India. The club has a rich history, having won numerous domestic and international titles, and has a massive following in the country.

History
--------

### Early years (1889–99)

Mohun Bagan was founded in 1889 by a group of Bengali football enthusiasts, led by Bhupendra Nath Bose, who was the first secretary of the club. The club was initially called Mohun Bagan Sporting Club and was based in the Mohun Bagan area of Kolkata. In its early years, the club played friendly matches against other local teams and slowly gained popularity.

### Administrative and tactical overhaul under Subedar-major Sailen Basu (1900s)

In the early 1900s, Subedar-major Sailen Basu took over as the secretary of the club and implemented several changes to improve the team's performance. He introduced a more organized and disciplined approach to the game, which helped the team to achieve better results. Under Basu's leadership, Mohun Bagan started to compete in local tournaments and eventually won its first major trophy, the Cooch Behar Cup, in 1904.

### The historic year of 1911

1911 was a historic year for Mohun Bagan, as the team won its first IFA Shield title, defeating East Yorkshire Regiment 2-1 in the final. This victory marked a significant milestone in the club's history, as it was the first time an Indian team had beaten a British team in a major tournament.

### Nation-wide exposure of the club (1912–30)

In the 1910s and 1920s, Mohun Bagan started to gain nation-wide recognition, as the team competed in various tournaments across India. The club won several titles, including the Durand Cup, the Rovers Cup, and the Cooch Behar Cup, which helped to establish its reputation as one of the top teams in the country.

### Significant contributions to the national team (1931–47)

During the 1930s and 1940s, Mohun Bagan played a significant role in the development of the Indian national team. Several players from the club were selected to represent India in international tournaments, including the 1936 Summer Olympics. The club's players also helped India to win its first major international title, the Quadrangular Tournament, in 1949.

### Struggle with consistency (1948–1950s)

In the late 1940s and 1950s, Mohun Bagan struggled to maintain its consistency, as the team faced stiff competition from other top teams in the country. The club went through a period of transition, as several key players retired or left the team, and it took some time for the team to rebuild and regain its former glory.

### The golden team (1960-64)

The 1960s saw the emergence of a new generation of talented players at Mohun Bagan, which formed the basis of the club's "golden team." This team, led by players like Chuni Goswami, Jarnail Singh, and Subhash Bhowmick, won several titles, including the Calcutta Football League, the IFA Shield, and the Durand Cup.

### Decline and revival under P. K. Banerjee (1965-1970s)

In the late 1960s and 1970s, Mohun Bagan went through a period of decline, as the team struggled to compete with other top teams in the country. However, under the leadership of P. K. Banerjee, who took over as the coach of the team in 1970, Mohun Bagan started to revive its fortunes. Banerjee introduced a more modern and scientific approach to the game, which helped the team to regain its former glory.

### The National Club of India (1980s)

In the 1980s, Mohun Bagan was officially recognized as the "National Club of India" by the All India Football Federation (AIFF). This recognition was a testament to the club's rich history and its contributions to Indian football.

### Commercialisation and incoming of foreigners (1990–2000)

In the 1990s, Mohun Bagan started to feel the effects of commercialization, as the club faced increased competition from other teams with more resources. The club also started to recruit foreign players, which helped to improve its performance and attract more fans.

### Heightened foreign influence (2000–2010)

In the 2000s, Mohun Bagan continued to recruit foreign players, which helped the team to maintain its competitiveness. The club also started to invest in its infrastructure, including the construction of a new stadium and training facilities.

### Strive for success and ultimate takeover by KGSPL (2010–20)

In the 2010s, Mohun Bagan continued to strive for success, as the team competed in various tournaments and leagues. However, the club faced financial difficulties, which led to a takeover by the Kolkata Games and Sports Private Limited (KGSPL) in 2020.

### Newfound dominance (2020–)

Under the ownership of KGSPL, Mohun Bagan has experienced a newfound sense of dominance, as the team has invested heavily in its squad and infrastructure. The club has won several titles, including the I-League and the Calcutta Football League, and has established itself as one of the top teams in the country.

Club crest and kits
-------------------

### Kit manufacturers and sponsors

Mohun Bagan's kit manufacturers and sponsors have changed over the years. The club's current kit manufacturer is Puma, and its main sponsor is the Kolkata Games and Sports Private Limited (KGSPL).

Stadiums
---------

### Vivekananda Yuba Bharati Krirangan

Mohun Bagan's home stadium is the Vivekananda Yuba Bharati Krirangan, which is located in Kolkata. The stadium has a seating capacity of over 85,000 and is one of the largest stadiums in India.

### Mohun Bagan Ground

Mohun Bagan also has a training ground, known as the Mohun Bagan Ground, which is located in the Maidan area of Kolkata. The ground is used for training and friendly matches.

Supporters
------------

Mohun Bagan has a massive following in India, with fans from all over the country supporting the team. The club's fans are known for their passion and loyalty, and they play a significant role in the team's success.

Rivalries
------------

### Rivalry of the Big Three

Mohun Bagan has a long-standing rivalry with two other Kolkata-based teams, East Bengal and Mohammedan Sporting. The three teams are known as the "Big Three" of Kolkata football, and their matches against each other are always highly anticipated and closely watched.

#### Kolkata Derby

The Kolkata Derby is the name given to the matches between Mohun Bagan and East Bengal. The two teams have a long and intense rivalry, which is fueled by their geographical proximity and their competing claims to be the best team in Kolkata.

#### Mini Derby

The Mini Derby is the name given to the matches between Mohun Bagan and Mohammedan Sporting. While not as intense as the Kolkata Derby, the Mini Derby is still a highly anticipated and closely watched match.

Ownership
------------

Mohun Bagan is currently owned by the Kolkata Games and Sports Private Limited (KGSPL), which took over the club in 2020.

Management
------------

Mohun Bagan's management team is responsible for the day-to-day running of the club. The team includes the club's CEO, the coach, and other support staff.

Coaching staff
----------------

Mohun Bagan's coaching staff is led by the team's head coach, who is responsible for preparing the team for matches and developing the players. The coaching staff also includes assistant coaches, fitness trainers, and other support staff.

Players

### First-team squad

Mohun Bagan's first-team squad includes some of the best players in India. The team has a mix of experienced players and young talent, and is known for its attacking style of play.

### Top scorers

### Notable players

Mohun Bagan has had several notable players in its history, including Chuni Goswami, Jarnail Singh, and P. K. Banerjee.

Season overall

### Overview

Mohun Bagan has had a successful season overall, winning several titles and competing in various tournaments and leagues.

### Performance in AFC competitions

Mohun Bagan has competed in several AFC competitions, including the AFC Cup and the AFC Champions League. While the team has not had much success in these competitions, it has gained valuable experience and exposure.

Honours
----------

Mohun Bagan has won several honours in its history, including the I-League, the Calcutta Football League, and the Durand Cup.

Mohun Bagan Day
-----------------

### Campaign

Mohun Bagan Day is celebrated on July 29 every year, which marks the anniversary of the team's founding. The day is celebrated with various events and activities, including friendly matches and fan gatherings.

# Tournament

## Venue

The 2022 Orléans Masters was held at the Palais des Sports in Orléans, France. The venue has a seating capacity of 3,000 spectators and has hosted several international badminton tournaments in the past.

* Semi-finalists: 3,850 points
* Quarter-finalists: 3,030 points

article:
2022 Chinese military exercises around Taiwan

The 2022 Chinese military exercises around Taiwan refer to a series of military exercises conducted by the People's Liberation Army (PLA) of China around Taiwan in August 2022. The exercises were a response to the visit of Nancy Pelosi, the Speaker of the United States House of Representatives, to Taiwan on August 2, 2022. The exercises marked a significant escalation of tensions between China and Taiwan, as well as between China and the United States.

#Background

##Incursions into Taiwan ADIZ

In recent years, China has increased its military activities around Taiwan, including incursions into Taiwan's Air Defense Identification Zone (ADIZ). The ADIZ is an area of airspace around Taiwan that the Taiwanese military monitors for potential threats. China's incursions into the ADIZ have become more frequent and aggressive, with Chinese warplanes often crossing into the zone and engaging in provocative maneuvers.

##Escalation of tensions

Tensions between China and Taiwan have been escalating in recent years, driven by a number of factors. One key issue is the question of Taiwan's status, with China claiming sovereignty over the island and Taiwan insisting on its independence. China has also been increasing its military pressure on Taiwan, with a growing presence of Chinese warships and warplanes in the region.

The visit of Nancy Pelosi to Taiwan in August 2022 was seen as a significant provocation by China, which responded with a series of military exercises around the island. The exercises were widely seen as a demonstration of China's military power and its ability to respond to perceived threats to its sovereignty.

#Military exercises

The military exercises conducted by China around Taiwan in August 2022 were a major escalation of tensions in the region. The exercises involved a range of military assets, including warships, warplanes, and ballistic missiles. China also conducted live-fire drills in the waters around Taiwan, including the firing of missiles into the sea.

The exercises were widely condemned by Taiwan and its allies, including the United States. Taiwan's military was placed on high alert during the exercises, with warplanes scrambled to respond to Chinese incursions into the ADIZ. The United States also responded to the exercises, with warships and warplanes deployed to the region to monitor the situation.

#Reactions

##Japan

Japan was a key player in the response to China's military exercises around Taiwan. Japan's military was placed on high alert during the exercises, with warplanes scrambled to respond to Chinese incursions into the ADIZ. Japan also issued a statement condemning China's actions and calling for restraint.

##North Korea

North Korea was notable for its silence on the issue of China's military exercises around Taiwan. North Korea has traditionally been a close ally of China, but its response to the exercises was muted. Some analysts suggested that North Korea may have been seeking to avoid antagonizing the United States, with which it has been engaged in diplomatic efforts.

##Russia

Russia was a key supporter of China's military exercises around Taiwan. Russia's foreign ministry issued a statement backing China's actions and condemning the visit of Nancy Pelosi to Taiwan. Russia also conducted its own military exercises in the region, including joint drills with China.

##United States

The United States was a key player in the response to China's military exercises around Taiwan. The United States condemned China's actions and called for restraint, with the State Department issuing a statement expressing concern about the situation. The United States also deployed warships and warplanes to the region to monitor the situation.

#Aftermath

The aftermath of China's military exercises around Taiwan saw a significant escalation of tensions in the region. Taiwan's military remained on high alert, with warplanes scrambled to respond to Chinese incursions into the ADIZ. The United States also maintained a significant military presence in the region, with warships and warplanes deployed to monitor the situation.

The exercises also marked a significant deterioration in relations between China and the United States. The two countries have been engaged in a range of disputes in recent years, including trade and security issues. The exercises around Taiwan were seen as a major escalation of tensions between the two powers.

article:
2022 ATP Challenger Tour

The 2022 ATP Challenger Tour is the 45th season of the ATP Challenger Tour, which is the secondary professional tennis circuit organized by the Association of Tennis Professionals (ATP). The calendar comprises 184 tournaments, with prize money ranging from $37,520 to $159,360.

#Schedule

##January

The season began on January 3, 2022, with the Bendigo International and the Traralgon International 1 in Australia, and the Challenger de Tigre in Argentina. The month saw 14 tournaments take place across the globe, including the Canberra International, the Quimper Open, and the Cleveland Open.

##February

February featured 18 tournaments, including the Bengaluru Open, the Koblenz Open, and the Dallas Open. The month also saw the return of the ATP Challenger Tour to Chile, with the Concepción Open.

##March

March was the busiest month of the season so far, with 24 tournaments taking place. The month saw the inaugural edition of the Roseto degli Abruzzi Open in Italy, as well as the return of the ATP Challenger Tour to Mexico, with the San Luis Open.

##April

April featured 16 tournaments, including the Sarasota Open, the Savannah Challenger, and the Romagna Open. The month also saw the inaugural edition of the Salinas Open in Ecuador.

##May

May saw 20 tournaments take place, including the Bordeaux Open, the Heilbronn Open, and the Zagreb Open. The month also featured the return of the ATP Challenger Tour to Croatia, with the Zagreb Open.

##June

June featured 17 tournaments, including the Nottingham Open, the Surbiton Trophy, and the Bratislava Open. The month also saw the return of the ATP Challenger Tour to Poland, with the Poznań Open.

##July

July saw 14 tournaments take place, including the Braunschweig Open, the Iași Open, and the Indianapolis Open. The month also featured the inaugural edition of the Verona Open in Italy.

##August

August featured 19 tournaments, including the San Marino Open, the Meerbusch Open, and the Banja Luka Open. The month also saw the return of the ATP Challenger Tour to Serbia, with the Banja Luka Open.

##September

September saw 20 tournaments take place, including the Nonthaburi Open, the Cary Open, and the Szczecin Open. The month also featured the inaugural edition of the Pau Open in France.

##October

October featured 17 tournaments, including the Tiburon Open, the Fairfield Open, and the Ismaning Open.

##November

November saw 12 tournaments take place, including the Knoxville Open, the Charlottesville Open, and the Ortisei Open.

#Cancelled tournaments

Several tournaments were cancelled due to the COVID-19 pandemic, including the Bhilai Open, the Chennai Open, and the Lagos Open.

article:
Barbie the Album
================

Barbie the Album is the soundtrack to the 2023 film Barbie, starring Margot Robbie and Ryan Gosling. The album was released on July 21, 2023, through Atlantic Records and features a diverse range of artists and genres.

Background
----------

The film's director, Greta Gerwig, wanted the soundtrack to reflect the movie's themes of female empowerment, self-discovery, and individuality. To achieve this, the album features a mix of established and emerging artists, including Billie Eilish, Dua Lipa, and Charli XCX. The soundtrack also includes original songs and re-recordings of classic hits, showcasing the versatility and creativity of the contributing artists.

Production
----------

Production on Barbie the Album began in 2022, with Gerwig working closely with music supervisor, Mary Ramos, to select and commission songs for the film. The album features contributions from over 20 artists, with many tracks written and produced specifically for the movie. The production process involved a collaborative effort between artists, songwriters, and producers to create a cohesive and engaging soundtrack that complements the film's narrative and tone.

Release
-------

Barbie the Album was released on July 21, 2023, through Atlantic Records, coinciding with the film's premiere in theaters. The album was available in various formats, including digital download, CD, and vinyl.

### Singles

Several singles were released from the album, including "What Was I Made For?" by Billie Eilish, "Dance the Night" by Dua Lipa, and "Angel" by Charli XCX. These singles received significant airplay and attention from music fans, generating excitement and buzz around the film and soundtrack.

### Best Weekend Ever Edition

A special edition of the album, titled Barbie the Album: Best Weekend Ever Edition, was released on August 25, 2023. This edition features additional tracks and remixes, including a new single by Harry Styles.

Critical Reception
----------------

Barbie the Album received widespread critical acclaim, with many praising the album's diversity, creativity, and cohesion. Reviewers noted the soundtrack's ability to capture the film's themes and tone, with many tracks showcasing the artists' unique styles and perspectives.

Commercial Performance
-------------------

Barbie the Album was a commercial success, debuting at number one on the US Billboard 200 chart and reaching the top 10 in several countries, including the UK, Australia, and Canada. The album has been certified gold in several countries, with many tracks receiving significant airplay and streaming activity.

Accolades

article:
Zillennials

Zillennials are a micro-generation of people born in the late 1990s and early 2000s, typically defined as those born between 1992 and 1998. This generation falls between the Millennial and Generation Z demographics, hence the portmanteau "Zillennials." They share characteristics with both Millennials and Gen Zers, but also exhibit distinct traits shaped by their unique experiences and cultural context.

#Etymology
The term "Zillennials" emerged as a colloquialism to describe individuals who identify with aspects of both Millennials and Gen Z. It is derived from the combination of "Z" from Generation Z and "Millennials." The term gained popularity on social media platforms, particularly among those who felt that they did not fit neatly into either the Millennial or Gen Z categories.

#Birth date and age range
Zillennials are generally considered to be individuals born between 1992 and 1998. This age range places them at the cusp of the Millennial and Gen Z generations. As of 2023, Zillennials are in their mid-to-late 20s to early 30s.

#Characteristics
Zillennials exhibit a unique blend of characteristics shaped by their experiences growing up during a time of significant technological, social, and economic change.

##Arts and culture
Zillennials grew up during a time of rapid technological advancements, which had a profound impact on the way they consume and interact with arts and culture. They are familiar with traditional forms of media, such as television and print, but also have a strong online presence. Zillennials are known for their eclectic taste in music, fashion, and art, often blending elements from different eras and styles.

##Economic activity
Zillennials entered the workforce during a time of economic uncertainty, marked by the Great Recession and its aftermath. As a result, they are often characterized as being pragmatic and risk-averse when it comes to financial decision-making. Many Zillennials prioritize stability and security over entrepreneurship and innovation.

##Health
Zillennials are known for their focus on mental and physical well-being. They prioritize self-care and are more likely to seek help for mental health issues than previous generations. Zillennials are also more health-conscious, with a greater emphasis on fitness, nutrition, and wellness.

##Personal values
Zillennials are often described as being socially conscious and empathetic. They prioritize authenticity, diversity, and inclusivity, and are more likely to engage in activism and volunteerism than previous generations.

##Political activity
Zillennials are known for their involvement in social and political movements, such as climate activism, LGBTQ+ rights, and racial justice. They are more likely to participate in online activism, using social media platforms to raise awareness and mobilize support for social causes.

##Social life
Zillennials value close relationships and are known for their strong social connections. They prioritize quality over quantity, often preferring to maintain a smaller circle of close friends rather than a large network of acquaintances.

##Technology
Zillennials grew up during a time of rapid technological change, and as a result, they are highly proficient in digital technologies. They are familiar with a wide range of platforms and tools, from social media to productivity software.

* Millennials
* Generation Z
* Micro-generation
* Social media
* Digital native

article:
2023 Alberta general election

The 2023 Alberta general election was held on May 29, 2023, to elect the members of the Legislative Assembly of Alberta. The election was called by Premier Danielle Smith on May 1, 2023, and the writs were dropped on the same day.

Background
----------

The 2023 Alberta general election was the 31st general election in the province of Alberta, Canada. The election was held to elect the members of the Legislative Assembly of Alberta, which is the unicameral legislature of the province. The election was contested by the major parties in Alberta, including the United Conservative Party (UCP), the New Democratic Party (NDP), the Alberta Party, and the Liberal Party.

Procedure
----------

The election was held using a first-past-the-post system, where voters in each electoral district voted for their preferred candidate, and the candidate with the most votes in each district was elected as the member of the Legislative Assembly. The election was administered by Elections Alberta, which is an independent agency responsible for the administration of elections in the province.

Electoral system
----------------

The electoral system used in the 2023 Alberta general election was a single-member plurality system, where each electoral district elected one member to the Legislative Assembly. The province was divided into 87 electoral districts, each with approximately 40,000 voters. The electoral districts were redrawn in 2020 to reflect changes in population and to ensure that each district had a similar number of voters.

Timeline
--------

### 2019

The 2019 Alberta general election was held on April 16, 2019, and the United Conservative Party (UCP) won a majority government, with 63 seats in the Legislative Assembly. The New Democratic Party (NDP) became the official opposition, with 24 seats.

### 2020

In 2020, the UCP government introduced a bill to reduce the number of electoral districts from 87 to 79. However, the bill was later withdrawn due to opposition from the NDP and other parties.

### 2021

article:
Colorado Springs Nightclub Shooting

The Colorado Springs nightclub shooting was a mass shooting that occurred on November 19, 2022, at Club Q, a gay nightclub in Colorado Springs, Colorado. The shooting resulted in the deaths of five people and injured 25 others, making it one of the deadliest mass shootings in the United States in 2022.

#Background

Club Q was a popular gay nightclub in Colorado Springs, known for its drag shows, karaoke nights, and other events catering to the LGBTQ+ community. The club had been in operation for over 20 years and was considered a safe space for members of the community. Colorado Springs has a significant LGBTQ+ population, and Club Q was one of the few establishments that catered to their needs.

In the months leading up to the shooting, there had been a rise in anti-LGBTQ+ rhetoric and violence across the United States. Several high-profile incidents had occurred, including the shooting at a gay bar in Florida and the vandalism of a gay pride monument in California. However, there was no indication that Club Q had been specifically targeted or threatened.

#Shooting

On the evening of November 19, 2022, a gunman entered Club Q and opened fire on the patrons. The shooting occurred at around 11:57 pm, just before midnight. The gunman was armed with a semi-automatic rifle and a handgun, and was wearing a flak jacket and a mask.

Eyewitnesses described the scene as chaotic, with patrons running for cover and attempting to flee the club. The gunman moved through the club, shooting indiscriminately, before being confronted by two patrons who managed to disarm him. The patrons, who were later identified as Thomas James and Richard Fierro, subdued the gunman and held him until police arrived.

Police responded to the scene within minutes, and the gunman was taken into custody at 12:02 am on November 20, 2022. The victims were rushed to nearby hospitals, where five were pronounced dead.

article:
Jerry Springer
================

Gerald Norman Springer, known professionally as Jerry Springer, was a British-American television presenter, former lawyer, politician, and actor. He was best known for hosting the tabloid talk show "The Jerry Springer Show" from 1991 to 2018, which became infamous for its outrageous and often violent guests.

Early life
-----------

Jerry Springer was born on February 13, 1944, in Highgate, London, England, to Jewish parents, Richard Springer and Margot Kallmann. His parents were refugees from Nazi Germany who fled to England before the outbreak of World War II. Springer's maternal grandmother was killed at the Theresienstadt concentration camp.

When Springer was five years old, his family moved to Cincinnati, Ohio, where he spent most of his childhood. He attended Forest Hills High School and was a member of the school's debate team. Springer graduated from Tulane University in 1965 with a Bachelor of Arts degree in political science. He later earned a Juris Doctor degree from Northwestern University in 1968.

Career
--------

### Kennedy campaign and early law career

Springer's interest in politics began at a young age. He worked as a volunteer for the presidential campaign of Senator Robert F. Kennedy in 1968. After Kennedy's assassination, Springer returned to Ohio and began practicing law. He worked as a lawyer for several years, specializing in corporate law.

### Political career

In 1971, Springer was elected to the Cincinnati City Council, where he served for five years. During his tenure, he was known for his progressive views and his support for social justice causes. Springer also served as the mayor of Cincinnati from 1977 to 1978.

### Broadcast career

#### Jerry Springer (1991–2018)

In 1991, Springer began hosting "The Jerry Springer Show," a tabloid talk show that featured guests with outrageous and often violent stories. The show quickly gained popularity and became known for its over-the-top guests and Springer's charismatic hosting style. The show ran for 27 seasons and became one of the longest-running tabloid talk shows in television history.

#### Judge Jerry (2019–2022)

In 2019, Springer began hosting a new show called "Judge Jerry," a courtroom reality show where he presided over small claims cases. The show was similar to other courtroom reality shows like "Judge Judy" and "Judge Mathis." "Judge Jerry" ran for three seasons before being canceled in 2022.

#### Other

In addition to his work on "The Jerry Springer Show" and "Judge Jerry," Springer has appeared on numerous other television shows, including "Dancing with the Stars," "The Simpsons," and "Family Guy."

#### UK

Springer has also worked in British television, hosting several shows, including "The Wright Stuff" and "Sunday Scoop." He has also appeared on British reality shows like "I'm a Celebrity...Get Me Out of Here!" and "Strictly Come Dancing."

In the media
------------

### Acting

Springer has appeared in several films and television shows as an actor, including "Ringmaster" (1998), "Citizen Toxie: The Toxic Avenger IV" (2000), and "Austin Powers in Goldmember" (2002).

### Television appearances

Springer has made numerous television appearances, including on shows like "The Tonight Show with Jimmy Fallon," "Conan," and "The Daily Show with Trevor Noah." He has also been a guest on several podcasts, including "The Adam Carolla Show" and "The Joe Rogan Experience."

Other projects
--------------

Springer has been involved in several other projects, including a stage production of "Chicago" and a USO tour. He has also written an autobiography, "Ringmaster!," which was published in 1998.

Personal life
-------------

Springer has been married twice, first to Micki Velton from 1973 to 1994, and then to Heather Jones from 1996 to 2006. He has one child, a daughter named Katie, who was born in 1976.

Death and legacy
----------------

Jerry Springer passed away on April 27, 2023, at the age of 79. He died peacefully at his home in Chicago, surrounded by his family.

Springer's legacy is complex and multifaceted. He is remembered for his charismatic hosting style and his ability to bring attention to social justice causes. However, he is also criticized for his role in perpetuating the tabloid talk show genre and its often exploitative treatment of guests.

The Flash Season 9

The ninth and final season of the American superhero television series The Flash premiered in 2023 on The CW. The season is based on the DC Comics character Barry Allen / Flash, a crime scene investigator who gains the ability to move at superhuman speeds, which he uses to fight crime and protect Central City.

# Episodes

The ninth season of The Flash consists of 13 episodes, which concludes the story of Barry Allen and his allies as they face their greatest challenge yet. The season premiered on February 8, 2023, and the finale aired on May 24, 2023.

1. "Wednesday Ever After"

# Production

### Development

The ninth season of The Flash was officially announced in April 2022, with Eric Wallace returning as showrunner. Wallace stated that the season would be the final one, and that it would conclude the story of Barry Allen and his allies.

### Writing

Wallace described the ninth season as "the most emotional season we've ever done", and said that it would explore the characters' personal relationships and backstories. The season's storylines were heavily influenced by the comic book series "The Flash: Rebirth" and "Flashpoint".

### Casting

The main cast from the previous seasons returned, with some changes to the recurring and guest cast. Javicia Leslie reprised her role as Ryan Wilder / Batwoman, while Natalie Dreyfuss and Thomas Mann made guest appearances.

### Filming

Filming for the ninth season began in September 2022 and concluded in March 2023. The season was primarily filmed in Vancouver, British Columbia, with some scenes shot in Los Angeles.

# Release

The ninth season of The Flash premiered on February 8, 2023, on The CW. The season finale aired on May 24, 2023.

# Notes

* The ninth season was the final season of the series, and concluded the story of Barry Allen and his allies.
* The season received positive reviews from critics, who praised the performances of the cast and the emotional storytelling.
* The season's finale, "A New World, Part 4 - The Last Stand", was watched by 1.02 million viewers, making it the highest-rated episode of the season.

article:
2022 Karnataka Hijab Row

The 2022 Karnataka hijab row was a controversy surrounding the wearing of hijabs by Muslim students in educational institutions in the Indian state of Karnataka. The issue sparked widespread protests, debates, and violence, eventually reaching the courts. The controversy highlighted the complex relationships between religion, education, and the law in India.

#Background

The wearing of hijabs by Muslim women is a common practice in many parts of India, particularly in the southern states, including Karnataka. However, the issue of hijabs in educational institutions has been a topic of debate for several years. In 2018, a government college in Udupi, Karnataka, had banned the wearing of hijabs, citing a uniform dress code policy. The issue had largely subsided until 2021, when a group of Muslim students at a pre-university college in Udupi sought permission to wear hijabs to class.

#Events

##Udupi dispute

In December 2021, a group of six Muslim students at the Government Pre-University College for Girls in Udupi approached the college authorities seeking permission to wear hijabs to class. The students claimed that wearing hijabs was an essential part of their faith and that they had been doing so for several years without any issues. However, the college authorities refused to grant them permission, citing a uniform dress code policy that had been in place since 2009.

##Saffron protests

In response to the college authorities' refusal, the six Muslim students decided to protest by wearing hijabs to class. However, their protest was met with counter-protests by a group of Hindu students who wore saffron shawls to class. The saffron protests quickly gained momentum, with more and more students joining in. The protests soon spread to other colleges and universities in Karnataka, with many Hindu students wearing saffron shawls and Muslim students wearing hijabs.

##Government reaction

The Karnataka government, led by Chief Minister Basavaraj Bommai, initially refused to intervene in the issue, stating that it was a matter for the educational institutions to decide. However, as the protests gained momentum, the government was forced to act. In January 2022, the government issued an order stating that students should adhere to the uniform dress code policy and not wear any religious attire to class.

##Fallout

The government's order was met with widespread protests and violence. Many Muslim students refused to comply with the order, citing their right to freedom of religion. The issue soon took on a communal tone, with many Hindus and Muslims clashing on the streets. The violence resulted in several injuries and arrests, and the government was forced to deploy police personnel to maintain law and order.

#Petitions in the High Court

##Religious rights

A group of Muslim students approached the Karnataka High Court, challenging the government's order and seeking a declaration that wearing hijabs was an essential part of their faith. The petitioners argued that the government's order was a violation of their right to freedom of religion, guaranteed under Article 25 of the Indian Constitution.

##Government order

The government, on the other hand, argued that the order was necessary to maintain peace and order in educational institutions. The government claimed that the wearing of hijabs was not an essential part of Islam and that the students could still practice their faith without wearing hijabs to class.

##College development committees

The Karnataka High Court, in its interim order, directed the college development committees to decide on the uniform dress code policy. However, the committees were unable to reach a consensus, and the issue remained unresolved.

##Udupi college and other institutions

The Udupi college, where the controversy had started, refused to allow Muslim students to wear hijabs to class. However, many other institutions, including private colleges and universities, allowed students to wear hijabs.

#High Court verdict

In March 2022, the Karnataka High Court delivered its verdict, dismissing the petitions filed by the Muslim students. The court held that wearing hijabs was not an essential part of Islam and that the government's order was necessary to maintain peace and order in educational institutions.

#Supreme Court

The Muslim students approached the Supreme Court, challenging the High Court's verdict. However, the Supreme Court refused to grant a stay on the High Court's order, stating that it would hear the matter at a later date.

#Violence

The controversy surrounding the hijab row resulted in widespread violence and communal clashes. Many Muslim students were attacked and injured by Hindu students, and several police personnel were also injured in the clashes.

#Reactions

##Domestic

The hijab row sparked widespread debate and discussion in India, with many politicians, activists, and scholars weighing in on the issue. Many Muslims argued that the government's order was a violation of their right to freedom of religion, while many Hindus argued that the wearing of hijabs was a threat to national unity.

##International

The hijab row also attracted international attention, with many countries and organizations expressing concern over the issue. The United Nations, the European Union, and the Organization of Islamic Cooperation all issued statements calling for respect for human rights and freedom of religion.

##Ministry of External Affairs (MEA)

The Indian Ministry of External Affairs (MEA) responded to international criticism, stating that the issue was an internal matter and that India was committed to protecting the rights of all its citizens.

#Impact

The hijab row had a significant impact on the educational system in Karnataka, with many Muslim students being forced to choose between their faith and their education. The controversy also highlighted the complex relationships between religion, education, and the law in India.

#Rescission

In August 2022, the Karnataka government rescinded its order banning the wearing of hijabs in educational institutions. The government stated that it had taken the decision in response to the Supreme Court's observations that the order was prima facie unconstitutional.

2023 SEA Games

The 2023 Southeast Asian Games, officially known as the 32nd Southeast Asian Games, is a multi-sport event that took place in Phnom Penh, Cambodia from May 5 to May 17, 2023. This was the first time Cambodia hosted the SEA Games, and the event marked a significant milestone in the country's sports development. The Games brought together athletes from 11 countries in Southeast Asia, competing in 37 sports and 579 events.

# Host selection

The host selection process for the 2023 SEA Games began in 2015, when Cambodia expressed its interest in hosting the event. The country was officially awarded the hosting rights in 2015, during the 29th SEA Games in Singapore. Cambodia's bid was unopposed, and the country was given a seven-year preparation period to host the event.

# Development and preparation

## Venues

A total of 26 venues were used for the 2023 SEA Games, with 18 of them being newly built or renovated specifically for the event. The main venue was the Morodok Techo National Sports Complex, which served as the centerpiece for the Games. Other notable venues included the Olympic Stadium, the National Swimming Center, and the Basketball Arena.

## Budget

The estimated budget for the 2023 SEA Games was $200 million, with the majority of the funds allocated for venue construction and renovation. The budget was significantly lower than the initial estimate of $400 million, due to cost-cutting measures and efficient planning.

## Volunteers

A total of 10,000 volunteers were recruited to support the 2023 SEA Games, with many of them being students and young adults from Cambodia and other Southeast Asian countries. The volunteers played a crucial role in ensuring the smooth operation of the event, from assisting athletes and officials to providing information and support to spectators.

## Torch relay

The torch relay for the 2023 SEA Games began on March 21, 2023, in the ancient city of Angkor Wat, and traveled through 17 provinces in Cambodia before reaching the Morodok Techo National Sports Complex on May 5, 2023. The torch was carried by over 1,000 torchbearers, including athletes, officials, and local residents.

## Ticketing, Broadcasting and Accommodations

Ticket sales for the 2023 SEA Games began in April 2023, with prices ranging from $5 to $50. The event was broadcast live on television and online platforms, with a total of 150 hours of coverage. Athletes and officials were accommodated in designated hotels and villages, with many of them staying in the newly built athletes' village at the Morodok Techo National Sports Complex.

# Participating nations

A total of 11 countries participated in the 2023 SEA Games, including Brunei, Cambodia, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, Myanmar, Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, Timor-Leste, and Vietnam.

# The Games

## Ceremonies

The opening ceremony of the 2023 SEA Games took place on May 5, 2023, at the Morodok Techo National Sports Complex, and featured a colorful display of music, dance, and cultural performances. The ceremony was attended by over 20,000 spectators, including dignitaries and officials from the participating countries.

### Parade of Nations

The parade of nations took place during the opening ceremony, with athletes and officials from each country marching into the stadium behind their national flags. The parade was led by the host country, Cambodia, and was followed by the other participating countries in alphabetical order.

## Sports

A total of 37 sports were featured at the 2023 SEA Games, including athletics, badminton, basketball, boxing, cycling, football, golf, gymnastics, hockey, and swimming. The event also included several new sports, such as esports, karate, and skateboarding.

## Calendar

The 2023 SEA Games took place over 12 days, from May 5 to May 17, 2023. The event schedule was packed, with many sports and events taking place simultaneously.

# Medal table

The medal table for the 2023 SEA Games was topped by Vietnam, which won a total of 136 medals, including 66 gold medals. Indonesia came second, with a total of 115 medals, while Thailand came third, with a total of 108 medals.

# Marketing

## Branding

The branding for the 2023 SEA Games was centered around the theme "Sports Live in Our Heart," which aimed to promote the event and encourage participation from athletes and spectators alike. The logo for the event featured a stylized image of the Angkor Wat temple, which is a symbol of Cambodia's rich cultural heritage.

## Sponsors

The 2023 SEA Games had several sponsors, including major brands such as Cambodia Angkor Air, Cambodia Brewery, and Petronas. The event also had several official suppliers, including sports equipment manufacturers and technology companies.

# Concerns and controversies

## IFMA-led boycott of Kun Khmer competition

The International Federation of Muaythai Associations (IFMA) led a boycott of the Kun Khmer competition at the 2023 SEA Games, citing concerns over the event's organization and judging standards. The boycott was supported by several countries, including Thailand and Indonesia.

## Participation and medal cap

There were concerns over the participation and medal cap for the 2023 SEA Games, with some countries accusing others of fielding too many athletes in certain sports. The issue was resolved through discussions between the participating countries and the SEA Games Federation.

## Upside down flag incident

During the opening ceremony of the 2023 SEA Games, the flag of the Philippines was accidentally displayed upside down. The incident sparked outrage and embarrassment, but was later rectified.

There were concerns over the organization of the 2023 SEA Games, with some athletes and officials complaining about the lack of information and support. The issue was addressed through improved communication and support services.

## Judging and match issues

There were several judging and match issues during the 2023 SEA Games, including disputes over scores and results. The issues were resolved through reviews and appeals processes.

## Player eligibility issues

There were concerns over player eligibility issues during the 2023 SEA Games, with some athletes being accused of not meeting the required eligibility criteria. The issue was addressed through investigations and disciplinary actions.

County Palatine of Durham

The County Palatine of Durham was a historic county in the north-east of England that existed from the 11th to the 19th centuries. As a palatine county, it was a territory ruled by a powerful nobleman, known as the Bishop of Durham, who wielded significant authority and autonomy within the county. The County Palatine of Durham played a unique and important role in the history of England, particularly during the medieval period.

# History

## Early history

The County Palatine of Durham has its roots in the 7th century, when the Kingdom of Northumbria was divided into several smaller territories. The area that would eventually become the County Palatine of Durham was initially part of the Kingdom of Bernicia, which was established by the Anglo-Saxon king Ida in 547. Following the Christianization of Northumbria in the 7th century, the kingdom was divided into several bishoprics, with the Bishop of Lindisfarne (later Durham) becoming one of the most powerful ecclesiastical authorities in the region.

## Establishment and consolidation

The County Palatine of Durham was formally established in the 11th century, following the Norman Conquest of England in 1066. William the Conqueror granted the Bishop of Durham, William de St-Calais, extensive powers and territories, including the right to govern the county in his own name. This grant, known as the "Liberty of Durham," gave the Bishop of Durham the authority to collect taxes, raise armies, and administer justice within the county. Over time, the County Palatine of Durham became a semi-autonomous territory, with its own laws, customs, and institutions.

During the medieval period, the County Palatine of Durham played a crucial role in the defense of northern England against Scottish raids and invasions. The Bishop of Durham was responsible for maintaining a large army and fortifying the county's borders, which helped to protect the region from external threats. The county also became an important center of trade and commerce, with the city of Durham serving as a major hub for the wool and textile industries.

## Decline and abolition

The County Palatine of Durham began to decline in importance during the 16th century, as the power of the Bishop of Durham was gradually eroded by the English monarchy. The English Reformation, which saw the Church of England break away from Rome, also led to a decline in the authority of the Bishop of Durham. In 1536, King Henry VIII abolished the Liberty of Durham, stripping the Bishop of Durham of his powers and reducing the county to a mere administrative division.

The County Palatine of Durham was formally abolished in 1836, when the Municipal Corporations Act created a new system of local government in England. The county was divided into several smaller administrative units, including the County Borough of Durham and the Rural District of Durham.

# Administration

## Taxation

The County Palatine of Durham had its own system of taxation, which was separate from the rest of England. The Bishop of Durham collected taxes from the county's inhabitants, which were used to fund the county's administration and defense. The county also had its own customs and excise system, which generated significant revenue from trade and commerce.

## Government and courts

The County Palatine of Durham had its own system of government and courts, which were separate from the rest of England. The Bishop of Durham served as the county's chief executive and judicial authority, and was responsible for appointing officials and judges to administer the county's laws. The county had its own court system, which included the Court of Chancery, the Court of Common Pleas, and the Court of King's Bench.

# St Cuthbert and the haliwerfolc

The County Palatine of Durham was closely associated with the cult of St Cuthbert, a 7th-century saint who was revered throughout northern England. The Bishop of Durham was responsible for governing the saint's shrine, which was located in Durham Cathedral, and for promoting the saint's cult throughout the county. The county's inhabitants, known as the haliwerfolc, were fiercely devoted to St Cuthbert and saw themselves as the saint's special people.

The cult of St Cuthbert played a significant role in the County Palatine of Durham's history and identity. The saint's shrine was a major pilgrimage site, and the county's inhabitants believed that St Cuthbert protected them from harm and brought them good fortune. The cult of St Cuthbert also helped to promote the county's sense of unity and identity, and played a significant role in shaping the county's laws, customs, and institutions.

# Legacy

The County Palatine of Durham played a unique and important role in the history of England, particularly during the medieval period. The county's semi-autonomous status and its close association with the cult of St Cuthbert made it a distinctive and fascinating place. Although the county was formally abolished in 1836, its legacy continues to be felt in the modern-day county of Durham, which remains a proud and distinct region with its own unique history and identity.

The County Palatine of Durham also played a significant role in shaping the history of northern England, particularly during the medieval period. The county's defense of the region against Scottish raids and invasions helped to protect the north of England from external threats, and its promotion of the cult of St Cuthbert helped to promote a sense of unity and identity throughout the region.

# Promptuarium Iconum Insigniorum

The Promptuarium Iconum Insigniorum is a comprehensive collection of portraits and biographies of notable figures from ancient and modern times. The work is a testament to the Renaissance humanist ideals of celebrating individual achievements and preserving historical memory. This article provides an overview of the Promptuarium Iconum Insigniorum, exploring its iconographic bases, authorship, publication history, reception, and significance in the context of Renaissance art and culture.

# Iconographic bases and authorship

## Iconographic influences

The Promptuarium Iconum Insigniorum draws inspiration from various iconographic sources, including ancient coins, medals, and sculptures. The work's author, Guillaume Rouillé, was a French antiquarian and printer who was fascinated by the art and culture of ancient civilizations. Rouillé's interest in iconography was likely influenced by the Renaissance humanist movement, which emphasized the study of classical texts and the revival of ancient artistic and cultural ideals.

## Authorship and contributors

Guillaume Rouillé is credited as the primary author of the Promptuarium Iconum Insigniorum. However, the work was likely a collaborative effort, involving contributions from various artists, engravers, and scholars. Rouillé's printing press, located in Lyon, France, was a hub for intellectual and artistic activity, attracting scholars and artists from across Europe. The Promptuarium Iconum Insigniorum reflects the collective efforts of these individuals, who worked together to create a comprehensive and visually stunning collection of portraits and biographies.

# Publication history

## First edition (1553)

The first edition of the Promptuarium Iconum Insigniorum was published in 1553 by Guillaume Rouillé's printing press in Lyon, France. The work was a groundbreaking achievement, featuring over 600 portraits and biographies of notable figures from ancient and modern times. These later editions reflect the ongoing interest in the work and the continued demand for a comprehensive collection of portraits and biographies of notable figures.

# Reception

## Renaissance humanism and the cult of fame

The Promptuarium Iconum Insigniorum was a product of the Renaissance humanist movement, which celebrated individual achievements and the pursuit of knowledge. The work reflects the Renaissance ideal of the "uomo universale," or the universal man, who excels in multiple fields and disciplines. The Promptuarium Iconum Insigniorum contributed to the cult of fame, which emerged during the Renaissance and emphasized the importance of individual reputation and achievement.

## Artistic and cultural significance

The Promptuarium Iconum Insigniorum is a significant work of Renaissance art and culture, reflecting the period's fascination with classical antiquity and the revival of ancient artistic and cultural ideals. The work's portraits and biographies provide a unique window into the intellectual and cultural landscape of the Renaissance, showcasing the era's most notable figures and achievements.

article:
2022 AFF U-16 Youth Championship

The 2022 AFF U-16 Youth Championship was the 13th edition of the AFF U-16 Youth Championship, a biennial international youth football tournament organized by the ASEAN Football Federation (AFF) for the men's under-16 national teams of Southeast Asia. The tournament took place in Indonesia from July 31 to August 12, 2022.

# Participant teams

A total of 12 teams participated in the tournament, with all 12 member associations of the AFF entering a team. The teams were:

*  Australia
*  Cambodia
*  Indonesia
*  Laos
*  Malaysia
*  Myanmar
*  Philippines
*  Singapore
*  Thailand
*  Timor-Leste
*  Vietnam

# Venues

The tournament was held in three venues in Indonesia:

* Gelora Bung Tomo Stadium in Surabaya
* Maguwoharjo Stadium in Sleman Regency
* Sultan Agung Stadium in Bantul Regency

# Draw

The draw for the tournament was held on June 30, 2022, in Jakarta, Indonesia. The 12 teams were drawn into three groups of four teams each. The teams were seeded based on their performance in the previous edition of the tournament.

# Group stage

The group stage took place from July 31 to August 6, 2022. The teams played each other in a round-robin format, with the top two teams from each group advancing to the knockout stage.

# Knockout stage

The knockout stage took place from August 9 to August 12, 2022. The teams played each other in a single-elimination format, with the winners advancing to the next round.
